    Strategies for Targeting Serine/Threonine Protein Phosphatases with Small Molecules in Cancer

    • Qiuyue Zhang
      Qiuyue Zhang
      State Key Laboratory of Natural Medicines and Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Drug Design and Optimization, China Pharmaceutical University, Nanjing 210009, China
      Department of Medicinal Chemistry, School of Pharmacy, China Pharmaceutical University, Nanjing 210009, China

    SUBJECTS:
    • Small molecules,
    • Targeting,
    • Inhibitors,
    • Cancer,
    • Peptides and proteins
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Among numerous posttranslational regulation patterns, phosphorylation is reversibly controlled by the balance of kinases and phosphatases. The major form of cellular signaling involves the reversible phosphorylation of proteins on tyrosine, serine, or threonine residues. However, altered phosphorylation levels are found in diverse diseases, including cancer, making kinases and phosphatases ideal drug targets. In contrast to the success of prosperous kinase inhibitors, design of small molecules targeting phosphatase is struggling due to past bias and difficulty. This is especially true for serine/threonine phosphatases, one of the largest phosphatase families. From this perspective, we aim to provide insights into serine/threonine phosphatases and the small molecules targeting these proteins for drug development, especially in cancer. Through highlighting the modulation strategies, we aim to provide basic principles for the design of small molecules and future perspectives for the application of drugs targeting serine/threonine phosphatases.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Phosphatases and kinases are enzymes that control the balance of the phosphorylation and dephosphorylation process (Figure 1A). Kinases transfer a phosphate group from adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to the substrate protein. Phosphatases remove the negatively charged phosphate groups from the target proteins through a water molecule. The addition or removal of a phosphate group, usually on tyrosine (Tyr), serine (Ser), or threonine (Thr) residues, activates or inactivates a protein through a conformational change.(1−3) This fundamental mechanism in eukaryotic organisms regulates multiple biological functions, including DNA replication, cell cycle progression, energy metabolism, and cell differentiation and development.(4−6) In this manner, most of them are involved in central processes in cancer and many other diseases.(7) Considering the fundamental role of reversible protein phosphorylation, protein kinases are regarded as promising drug targets, contributing to a large number of drug discovery programs by pharmaceutical manufacturers. Up to 2020, more than 60 different protein kinase inhibitors were launched on the market (www.brimr.org/PKI/PKIs.htm), which made kinases one of the most attractive drug targets (Figure 1B). Additionally, numerous clinical and preclinical processes are being developed, resulting in many views in the development of kinase inhibitors.(8) Although both kinases and phosphatases are equally important in pathological scenarios, rational design for phosphatase modulators faces tremendous challenges. As the majority of kinase inhibitors are designed to target ATP binding sites, initial efforts to develop phosphatase modulators were focused on targeting the catalytic active sites.(9,10) However, due to the highly conserved character of active sites on phosphatases and the negative charges are required to guarantee the tight binding, it is difficult to achieve ideal selectivity and bioavailability for phosphatase modulators. Thus, for a long time, phosphatases were regarded as “undruggable” targets of small molecules.(11,12)
    Recent evidence with successful cases provides possibilities for the rational design of small molecules targeting phosphatases (Figure 1B, https://clinicaltrials.gov).(13−15) According to the substrate features, most phosphatases are tyrosine and serine/threonine phosphatases.(16,17) For tyrosine phosphatases, targeting nonreceptor type 11, ptpn11, commonly called SHP2 for SH2-domain containing phosphatase-2, with small molecules (represented by SHP2 inhibitor TNO155 by Novartis) has received great interest in KRAS-driven cancers (NCT03114319).(18−20) Targeting protein tyrosine phosphatase 1B (PTP1B) with trodusquemine (MSI-1436 developed by Genaera Corporation) showed efficacy for obesity and type 2 diabetes (NCT00606112) and breast cancer (NCT02524951).(21,22) Notably, these inhibitors work in an allosteric binding manner rather than blocking the active sites, indicating that directly targeting the catalytic sites of phosphatases might not be an optimal method and that new methods are emerging. Considering that the small molecules targeting tyrosine phosphatases have been nicely introduced in previous reviews,(23−28) herein, we will focus on serine/threonine phosphatases, which are composed of a large number of family members with different regulatory mechanisms to provide opportunities for the design of small molecules with new concepts. In eukaryotic cells, more than 97% of all protein phosphorylation sites occur on serine/threonine residues.(1) Serine/threonine phosphatases are mainly composed of phosphoprotein phosphatases (PPPases) and metal-dependent protein phosphatases.(29) Notably, the PPPases family plays an essential role, as its members are responsible for 90% of serine/threonine dephosphorylation events.(30) In this review, we aim to mainly introduce PPPases as representative serine/threonine phosphatases. PPPases can be further divided into seven subfamilies, including protein phosphatase 1 (PP1), protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A), calcineurin (Cn, also known as PP2B or PP3), protein phosphatase 4 (PP4), protein phosphatase 5 (PP5), protein phosphatase 6 (PP6), and protein phosphatase 7 (PP7, also known as PPEF).(29) Although they share a common mechanism of metal-catalyzed dephosphorylation through highly conserved catalytic active sites, different PPPases exhibit specificity according to their diverse regulatory subunits or unique structural features, which provides potential opportunities for the rational design of small molecules.
    Among PPPases subfamilies, PP5 and PP7 work in monomeric enzyme form, while others work in holoenzyme form with the help of catalytic subunits, regulatory subunits, and/or scaffold subunits. Diverse compounds are under evaluation for their antiproliferation activity with different regulatory mechanisms, including targeting catalytic subunits, targeting noncatalytic subunits/domains, and targeting holoenzymes, which make PPPases potential drug targets in cancer. Among them, LB-100 (1, Table 1) shows antitumor effects against multiple types of cancer cells, such as hepatocellular carcinoma, pancreatic cancer, and ovarian cancer, by binding to the catalytic active sites of the PP2A catalytic subunit.(31−40) FTY720 (2, Table 1) exhibits antitumor activity in acute myeloid leukemia cells by combining with SET, an endogenous inhibitor of PP2A, to disrupt the PP2AC-SET interaction and selectively activate PP2A.(41−45) Both DT-061 and iHAP1 (respectively, 3 and 4, Table 1) work as “molecular glue” to selectively active PP2A by interacting with different PP2A holoenzymes with distinct B56 subunits and induce their antitumor activity against cancer cells.(14,15) Cyclosporine A and tacrolimus (respectively, 5 and 6, Table 1) selectively inhibit PP3 by targeting holoenzymes, showing antitumor effects against diverse cancer cells, including colorectal cancer, breast cancer, and bladder cancer cells.(46−48) In this review, we briefly introduce the structural characteristics and cancer-related biological functions of PPPases. According to the structural features of PPPases and the action mechanisms of modulators, the representative small-molecule modulators of PPPases are classified into three groups: (1) small molecules targeting catalytic subunits, (2) small molecules targeting noncatalytic subunits/domains, and (3) small molecules targeting holoenzymes. All of the current evidence demonstrates feasible approaches for the rational design of small molecules targeting PPPases with distinct patterns for cancer therapy, making these “undruggable” targets reborn.
    Table 1. List of the Representative PPPase Modulators

    2. Structure and Biological Function

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    2.1. Sequences and Structural Features of PPPases

    As shown in Figure 2A, the catalytic subunits of the PPPases superfamily are highly conserved in the sequence alignment. Especially, the catalytic cores in the catalytic subunits contain nine strictly conserved amino acids: Six amino acids (three His, two Asp, and one Asn) coordinate with a metal ion (including Mg2+, Mn2+, Fe2+, or Zn2+), and three of these amino acids (two Arg and one His) are responsible for the binding of the phosphate group. Additionally, all members of the PPPases family share a common catalytic mechanism that is dominated by two metal ions closely attached to the catalytic center. All the characteristics shown above imply a challenge for the design of selective small molecules by targeting catalytic sites. For example, calyculin A, okadaic acid, and microcystin-LR (respectively, 7, 8, and 9, Table 1) are PPPase inhibitors with high binding affinity, but they are not selective for PPPases.(49−51) Although PPPase members share common features, they can be distinguished by certain sequence characteristics and distinct regulatory subunits, which indicate the potential for the design of selective small molecules.
    In term of sequences, PP3, PP5, and PP7 can be distinguished from others by the unique N- and C-terminus of their catalytic subunits (Figure 2A). PP5 contains a tetratricopeptide repeat (TPR) domain (composed of three consecutive TPR motifs) in the N-terminus and an αJ helix in the C-terminus.(52) The TPR domain cooperates with the αJ helix and works as a switch together to control the activity of PP5.(53−55) Interestingly, both PP3 and PP7 are Ca2+-related PPPases with Ca2+-calmodulin binding motifs in their N- or C-terminal regions.(56,57) PP3 has three functional domains in the C-terminal region, including the calcineurin B (CnB) binding domain which interacts with the regulatory subunit, the Ca2+-calmodulin (CaM) binding domain which interacts with calcium and calmodulin (a calcium sensing protein), and the autoinhibitory (AI) domain which forms an α helix to block the substrates from entering the catalytic center.(58) The N-terminal CaM binding motif of PP7 is also named the IQ motif. Additionally, five noncontiguous Ca2+-binding EF-hand motifs in the C-terminus are a typical feature of PP7. The presence of Ca2+-calmodulin binding and EF-hand motifs implies that PP7 is under dual control.(56) In term of the structures, regulatory subunits and/or scaffold subunits make PPPases different from each other (Figure 2B). PP3 is a dimeric holoenzyme that consists of a catalytic subunit with three isoforms (PP3Cα, PP3Cβ, and PP3Cδ) and a Ca2+-binding regulatory subunit (calcineurin B) that contains four noncontiguous Ca2+ binding EF-hand domains, corresponding to the EF-hand motifs in PP7.(59) Similar to PP3, PP4 also works in a dimeric holoenzyme formed with one isoform of catalytic subunit.(29,60) The regulatory subunits of PP4 have five members, namely, PP4R1, PP4R2, PP4R3α, PP4R3β, and PP4R4. PP1 is a dimeric or trimeric holoenzyme that consists of a catalytic subunit with four isoforms (PP1Cα, PP1Cβ, PP1Cγ1, and PP1Cγ2) and one or two regulatory subunits. Currently, more than 200 regulatory subunits are identified as regulatory interactors of protein phosphatase one (RIPPOs), which provides the specificity for a large number of substrates.(30,61,62) PP2A and PP6 are trimeric holoenzymes. In addition to the catalytic subunit and regulatory subunit, they also have a scaffold subunit that mediates the interaction between catalytic subunit and regulatory subunit. PP2A consists of a catalytic subunit with two isoforms (PP2ACα and PP2ACβ), a regulatory subunit (at least 18 subunits have been discovered), and a scaffold subunit with two members (PP2AAα and PP2AAβ).(29) PP6 has one type of catalytic subunit, three types of regulatory subunits (PPP6R1, PPP6R2, and PPP6R3), and three types of scaffold subunits (ANR28, ANR44, and ANR52).(63,64)
    Although it is challenging to design small molecules directly targeting the catalytic cores, based on the sequences and structural features, it is ideal to regulate the functions of PPPases with different mechanisms. Specific functional domains and regulatory subunits are the determinants of the functional diversity and specificity of each PPPase, thereby making it possible to target these regulatory subunits or specific functional domains for the design of selective small molecules.

    2.2. Cancer-Related Biological Functions

    PPPases participate in the regulation of diverse cellular signaling pathways, such as RNA splicing, the DNA damage response, protein synthesis, cell cycle progression, mitosis, proliferation, migration, and apoptosis.(30,70−73) As shown in Figure 3A, more than 200 proteins have been identified as the substrates of PPPases (depod.bioss.unifreiburg.de/br_net.php).(56,65−69) Although a majority of the substrates have a one-to-one relationship with PPPases, this is just the current knowledge. In reality, this is even much more complicated, as only a few substrates have been directly assigned to one phosphatase, forming a complex dephosphorylation network. PPPases are closely related to the pathogenesis and development of many cancers. At the early stage, PPPases were simply identified as tumor suppressor proteins or oncogenic proteins. In recent years, accumulating evidence has indicated that PPPases play different roles in distinct cancers, which may be due to the diversity of regulatory subunits of PPPases.(74−90) Here, we list a few examples, mainly involving PP1, PP2A, and PP4 to illustrate that PPPases could act as both tumor promoters and tumor suppressors in specific cancers (Figure 3B).
    There is still a debate on the classification of PP1 as a tumor suppressor protein or an oncogenic protein. The different PP1C isoforms were rarely discriminated in early tumor studies, and they were considered to play overlapping roles. To date, growing evidence has indicated that different isoforms of PP1C have individual functions or even antagonizing functions. For example, knockdown of different isoforms of PP1C induced distinct cell phenotypes in HeLa cervical carcinoma cells.(74) PP1Cα knockdown induced cell rounding and increased proliferation inhibition; PP1Cβ knockdown led to cell flattening and enlargement, with enrichment of lamellipodia; and PP1Cγ1 knockdown changed the distribution of cell cycle phases. PP1Cα and PP1Cγ1 play antagonizing roles and display different functions in lung cancer cells.(75) For more details about the underlying mechanism, see the review by Felgueiras et al.(76) PP2A is another well-studied PPPase subfamily that was previously generally defined as a tumor suppressor.(77−80) Its two completely different roles in cancer were uncovered by later studies. For example, PR55α (a regulatory subunit) containing PP2A acts as a tumor promoter in pancreatic cancer by sustaining hyperactive tumor promoters, including YAP, AKT, ERK and Wnt;(81,82) PR61γ1 or PR61γ3 (PP2A regulatory subunit) containing PP2A acts as a tumor suppressor to stabilize p53 by dephosphorylating at either Ser37 or Thr55.(83,84) PP4 is also well-studied, and it play the opposite role in different cancers with different regulatory subunits. PPP4R1, a regulatory subunit of PP4, is overexpressed in many cancers, such as breast cancer,(90) lung cancer,(85) and hepatocellular carcinoma.(86) PPP4R1 knockdown induces cancer cell proliferation inhibition by downregulating cell cycle activators.(85) PPP4R1-containing PP4 accelerates cell proliferation, which may be regulated by the p38 and c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) pathways.(86) PP4C is overexpressed in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.(87) PPP4R2, another regulatory subunit of PP4, is recurrently deleted in acute myeloid leukemia, which induces the DNA damage repair (DDR) impairment by blocking the dephosphorylation of DDR-related proteins, including KRAB domain-associated protein 1 (KAP-1), histone variant H2AX (γH2AX), tumor protein p53 (TP53), and replication protein A2 (RPA2).(88,89) As shown above, PPPases cannot be simply identified as tumor promoters or tumor suppressors, and their role in cancer depends on their structure and the type of tumor.
    Considering the significant and changeable roles of PPPases in cancers, designing small-molecule activators or inhibitors targeting them provides chances to regulate cell growth, differentiation, migration and proliferation, which might be potential strategies for cancer therapy. Furthermore, selective small molecules targeting specific PPPases or even specific isoforms and regulatory subunits are necessary. Hence, effective strategies for identifying potential modulators are urgently needed.

    3. Small-Molecule Modulators of PPPases

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    For a long time, phosphatases have been regarded as “undruggable” targets as they have highly conserved catalytic sites with negative charges and unspecific profiles. However, in the past few decades, several natural compounds targeting PPPases, including cyclosporine A,(133) tacrolimus,(133) nodularin R (10),(135) microcystin-LR,(136) okadaic acid,(137) tautomycin (11),(135) calyculin A,(138) fostriecin (12),(139) cantharidin (13),(92) and endothall (14),(140) have been reported, which supports the feasibility of the rational design of small molecules targeting PPPases (Figure 4, Table 1). Interestingly, most of them bind to the catalytic active sites of PPPases and act as pan inhibitors with nanomolar to micromolar inhibitory activity to all PPPases subfamilies (Table 1). Notably, among these natural products, cyclosporine A and tacrolimus selectively inhibit PP3 by working as “molecular glue” that bind to all subunits of the holoenzyme and interact with noncatalytic sites. These natural products lay the foundation for the subsequent development of small molecules targeting PPPases, indicating that in addition to targeting the catalytic sites, targeting the specific functional domains or the unique subunits of PPPases could be other promising strategies. This viewpoint seems to be supported by several small molecules reported in recent years, such as Ro 90-7501 (a TPR-dependent PP5 inhibitor, 15),(122) and FTY720 (a PP2A activator, disrupting the PP2AC-SET interaction).(41−45) Additionally, targeting holoenzymes with the “molecular glue” (DT-061, iHAP1) have also been identified as a feasible strategy.(14,15) Here, based on the structural features of PPPases and the action mechanisms of modulators, the representative small-molecule modulators of PPPases are classified into three groups: (1) small molecules targeting catalytic subunits, (2) small molecules targeting noncatalytic subunits/domains, and (3) small molecules targeting holoenzymes. We briefly introduce the binding modes and the anticancer mechanisms of the representative compounds, which might provide potential clues for the subsequent development of selective small molecules targeting PPPases for cancer therapy.

    3.1. Small Molecules Targeting the Catalytic Subunits

    3.1.1. Cantharidin and Its Derivatives

    Cantharidin is a natural product extracted from Chinese blister beetles, and it is originally used to treat skin-related diseases in traditional Chinese medicine.(142) Recently, cantharidin was found to exhibit strong antitumor activity both in vitro and in vivo against various cancer cells, such as hepatocellular carcinoma cells and breast cancer cells.(91) Subsequently, Li and Casida first identified PP2A as a potential target for cantharidin, and Honkanen et al. reported its inhibitory activities against PP1 (IC50 = 1700 nM), PP2A (IC50 = 160 nM) and PP3 (lower inhibition).(92,143) As shown in Table 1, current studies have identified cantharidin as a pan inhibitor of PPPases (including PP1, PP2A, PP4, PP5, and PP6) with submicromolar inhibitory activity, and its underlying antitumor mechanism is mainly involved in the DNA damage and apoptosis.(49,50,144,145) Unfortunately, the unavoidable side effects of cantharidin on the gastrointestinal tract, ureter, heart, lungs, skin, kidney, and blood limit its further application.(146,147) Although cantharidin was not applied as a drug in cancer treatment, it guided the subsequent development of cantharidin-derived small molecules targeting PPPases.
    Norcantharidin (16, Figure 4 and Table 1), a demethylated form of cantharidin, is easier to synthesize and had less cytotoxicity and comparable inhibitory activities against PP1 (IC50 = 9000 nM) and PP2A (IC50 = 3000 nM). Norcantharidin exhibits antitumor activities in many tumors (Table 1) and has been used as a folk anticancer agent since 1984 in China.(93,96−106) Currently, norcantharidin has received increasing attention and a phase I trial is ongoing to evaluate the pharmacokinetics (PKs), safety, and tolerance of norcantharidin in the treatment of solid tumors (NCT04673396).
    Based on the inspiration of cantharidin and norcantharidin, a first-in-class small-molecule inhibitor targeting PP2A, LB-100, was discovered to have favorable membrane permeability properties and good tolerance in vivo.(107) Subsequently, LB-100 was proven to have stronger PP2A (IC50 = 400 nM) and PP5 (IC50 = 180 nM) inhibitory activities than norcantharidin.(13,107) LB-100 exhibited antitumor activities against a variety of cancer cells (for more details, see Table 1).(31−40) Many preclinical studies have shown that LB-100 acts as both a chemo- and radio-sensitizer that synergistically assists in enhancing the therapeutic effect of chemotherapy and radiotherapy on tumors without significant systemic toxicity.(148) In 2013, LB-100 successfully entered into a clinical study (NCT01837667) in combination with docetaxel and showed promising safety, tolerability, and antitumor profiles in patients with advanced solid tumors.(149) Currently, two phase II trials are ongoing to assess the safety and efficacy of LB-100 in the treatment of myelodysplastic syndromes (NCT03886662) and glioblastoma (NCT03027388).(13) The new mechanism and satisfactory preliminary clinical results support the further development of LB-100 as well as in combination with other therapies.(149) Although LB-100 inhibits both PP2A and PP5, the antitumor mechanism of LB-100 by inhibiting PP2A has been elucidated more comprehensively. PP2A inhibition by LB-100 regulates its downstream signaling pathways, including the Akt, homologous recombination repair (HRR) and hypoxia inducible factor-1α (HIF-1α) related signaling pathways, thus inhibiting the proliferation of cancer cells by promoting progenitor cells differentiation, drug penetration, mitotic mutation and apoptosis (Figure 5A).(148) Aberrant cell cycle progression promotes cancer cell sensitivity to chemotherapeutic agents. In the Akt pathway, PP2A inhibition can increase the level of phosphorylated Akt (pAkt), which represses the formation of the nuclear receptor corepressor (N-CoR) complex and increases the protein level of murine double (MDM2). Therefore, the N-CoR complex blocks the differentiation of astrocytes by inhibiting the transcription of related genes, thus resulting in cell differentiation.(31) The enhanced pAkt level induces a significant increase in the level of pMDM2, further suppressing p53, and induces mitotic catastrophe of cancer cells.(150) In addition, mitotic catastrophe is also observed after radiation therapy combined with LB-100. In radiated cells which are pretreated with LB-100, the levels of phosphorylated polo-like kinase 1 (PlK1) and cell division cycle 25c (Cdc25c) are increased and accumulate in G2/M cell cycle progression.(151) LB-100 improves chemotherapeutic agents for penetrating into the bulk of the tumor by increasing tumor angiogenesis and perfusion.(152) In the HIF-1α pathway, the inhibition of PP2A increases HIF-1α and induces vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) secretion. HRR is one of the main DNA protection mechanisms that acts by inducing the apoptosis of DNA damaged cells. PP2A has also been demonstrated to upregulate the HRR pathway activity.(153) The radio-sensitizing potential of LB-100 is achieved by inhibiting PP2A and decreasing the HRR repair.(154)
    Although no cocrystal structure of PP2A-LB-100 has been reported, a cocrystal structure of PP5-LB-100 (PDB code: 5WG8)(107) was solved at 1.65 Å in 2019.(13,107) It shows that LB-100 coordinates tightly within the catalytic pocket through multitype interactions (including ionic interactions, hydrogen bonds, hydrophobic and dipole–dipole stacking interactions) (Figure 5B). Compared with the PP5-phosphates complex (PDB code: 1S95),(141) the O7 bridging oxygen of LB-100 replaces the active water molecule and the hydroxide of phosphates to coordinate with M2, blocking the access of phosphate group. The side chains of Arg275 and Tyr451 are shifted away from the catalytic metals to accommodate the inhibitor. Therefore, all the evidence proved that LB-100 inhibits PP5 and PP2A by competitively occupying the substrate-binding sites. The binding mode of LB-100 indicates possible features of PPPases catalytic sites that can be occupied by small molecule and it will provide a valuable reference for further design of small molecules targeting PPPases.

    3.1.2. Fostriecin

    Fostriecin is an active extract of Streptomyces pulveraceus that exhibits antitumor activities against leukemia, lung cancer, breast cancer, and ovarian cancer.(119,120) In the early stage, DNA topoisomerase II was considered the target of fostriecin, but its inhibitory activity (IC50 = 40 μM) was weak.(156) Unlike other topoisomerase II inhibitors, G2 arrest in the cell cycle was not observed after treatment with fostriecin.(156) Subsequently, fostriecin was found to prevent the mitotic entry checkpoint by inhibiting PPPases, which was considered to be a more reliable antitumor mechanism. To date, the inhibitory activities of fostriecin against PP1, PP2A, PP3, PP4, and PP5 have been determined (IC50 = 45–58 μM, 1.5–5.5 nM, >100 μM, 3.0 nM, and 50–70 μM, respectively).(49,139,157,158) As shown in Table 1, fostriecin inhibits PP2A/PP4 more 10000-fold than other PPPases.
    In 2004, a preliminary phase I clinical study of fostriecin was conducted in patients with refractory advanced or metastatic cancer to evaluate maximum-tolerated dose (MTD), toxicity, and PK profiles. Unfortunately, this study was terminated before reaching the MTD due to instability in storage and unpredictable purity.(118) Nowadays, although the synthesis problem of fostriecin has been solved, the storage stability of fostriecin is still a problem that urgently needs to be addressed.(159−161) When combined with carboplatin in ovarian cancer therapy, fostriecin can increase chemosensitivity, DNA damage, and micronuclei formation.(162) The underlying antitumor mechanism includes the regulation of the DDR pathway mediated by PP4.(162) Generally, the inhibition of PP4 will promote the activation of signal transducer and activator of transcription 1 (STAT1), thereby increasing the expression of proinflammatory cytokines and triggering an antitumor immune response (Figure 6A).
    Although there is currently no cocrystal structure of the fostriecin-PPPases complex, Toshifumi Takeuchi et al. demonstrated that fostriecin acts as a covalent-binding inhibitor of PP2A/PP4 by mass spectrometry analysis.(163) The electrophilic α,β-unsaturated δ-lactone moiety of fostriecin is nucleophilically attacked by Cys269 of PP2A (Figure 6B). Notably, Cys269 is a highly conserved amino acid among PP2A, PP4, and PP6, which may explain the weak inhibition of fostriecin to PP1, PP3, and PP5.

    3.1.3. Microcystins

    Microcystins (MCs) are cyclic peptide toxins extracted from cyanotoxins, and they are widely distributing in drinkable water, which is a growing environmental and health concern.(165−167) MCs exposure will induce long-term carcinogenic toxicity, hepatotoxicity, or even acute poisoning based on different dosages.(168−172) The toxicity mechanism mainly involves PP1 and PP2A inhibition with high affinities.(173,174) Additionally, MCs also inhibit other PPPases subfamilies, including PP3, PP4, PP5, and PP6, with fewer studies.(51,175) Cocrystal structures of microcystin-LR (a congener of MCs) with PP1C (PDB ID:1FJM)(164) and PP2AC (PDB ID: 2IE3)(155) have been reported, which revealed the binding feature and inhibitory mechanism of MCs. As shown in Figure 7, microcystin-LR attaches to the catalytic subunits of PPPases through multiple interactions, involving hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, and covalent bonds. Microcystin-LR forms a covalent bond with Cys273 in PP1 and Cys269 in PP2A, which are conserved in PPPases attributing to the high affinities and the lack of selectivity of MCs.(164,176−179) Subsequently, based on an SAR study and rational modifications of MCs, Aggen et al. identified a selective PP1 inhibitor, compound 1 (17, Figure 4), that has 7-fold selectivity toward PP1.(180) In 2018, Köhn’s group identified a highly selective submicromolar PP2A inhibitor, compound 2 (18, Figure 4), over PP1 (282-fold selectivity) based on MCs.(181) In the future, after clarifying the relationship between toxicity and structure, MCs scaffolds may be used to develop specific inhibitors to treat PP1/PP2A-related cancers.(182)

    3.1.4. Tautomycetin

    Tautomycetin (TTN, 19, Figure 4 and Table 1) and tautomycin (TTM) are natural compounds isolated from bacteria and show antitumor and immunosuppressive activities.(183−185) Both of them share similar structures and show PP1/PP2A inhibitory activities.(186) In 2017, Honkanen’s group tested the inhibitory activity of TTN toward PPPases (Table 1) and revealed the PP1 specificity mechanism through a cocrystal structure of PP1-TTN (PDB ID: 6ALZ).(114) The result of PPPases inhibition shows that TTN selectively inhibits PP1 at the picomolar level (IC50 = 38 pM), while the inhibitory activities on other PPPases are at nanomolar levels (Table 1). As shown in Figure 8, a complex interaction network is formed, including salt bridges, hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, and covalent bonds. The diacid head of TTN binds the PP1 active sites, and the diene/alkene group tail extends to the hydrophobic groove and forms a covalent bond with Cys127. According to a cocrystal constructure of PP1-TTM (PDB ID: 3E7B),(135) although TTM adapts a similar conformation to bind PP1, it does not form a covalent bond because the diene/alkene group in TTN is replaced with the spiroketal group in TTM. The Cys127 (corresponding to the Cys153 in PP3) specifically exists in PP1 and PP3, while the formation of covalent bonds is blocked by the steric hindrance of His155 and Val253 side chain of PP3, which explains the specific inhibition of PP1 by TTN.(114)
    In addition to the small molecules mentioned above, there are many other compounds have been reported as PPPase inhibitors, such as nodularin R,(108) okadaic acid,(49−51,112) and calyculin A,(49−51) that target the catalytic active sites. Most of them have reported cocrystal structures with PPPases, supporting many details in binding features with catalytic regions on different PPPases.
    In summary, many small molecules have been reported to modulate PPPases by binding to the catalytic subunits, and it has been turned out that targeting catalytic subunits is a feasible way for cancer therapy with some of these molecules have entered clinical studies. Even so, there are still many issues that need to be addressed, such as storage stability and selectivity. Fostriecin is a potential PP2A/PP4 inhibitor for cancer therapy, but the problem of storage instability blocks further clinical study and urgently needs to be addressed. Most of the modulators mentioned above act as pan-inhibitors and may cause unpredictable toxicities due to the complex biological functions of PPPases (for more details, see Section 2.2). Fortunately, abundant cocrystal structure data have been reported that may provide some clues for the development of selective inhibitors by targeting the catalytic active sites of PPPases. For instance, by aligning their sequences and analyzing the key binding sites based on the known cocrystal structures to find specific amino residues, small molecules can be designed by targeting these specific amino residues. This might be a direct and promising strategy for developing selective small-molecule modulators.

    3.2. Small Molecules Targeting Noncatalytic Subunits/Domains

    3.2.1. FTY720

    FTY720 (also known as fingolimod) is a synthetic compound modified from myriocin (ISP-1, 20, Figure 9), a metabolite from Isaria sinclairii.(130) Initially, FTY720 was developed as an immunosuppressive agent for the treatment of multiple sclerosis and approved by the FDA in 2010.(187) In the past few years, FTY720 was reported to induce apoptosis in various cancers, such as breast cancer, bladder cancer, prostate cancer, glioma, and leukemia.(124−130) Matsuoka et al. demonstrated that the apoptotic effects of FTY720 are achieved by activating PP2A (Figure 9A).(124) They determined that FTY720 activates PP2A to 175% of its basal activity at a 10 μM concentration and has no effects on PP1. The PP2A activation mechanism of FTY720 is identified to involve PP2AC-SET interaction disruption.(43,44) FTY720 activates PP2A by directly binding with the C-terminus (177–277 aminos) of SET, which is a known oncoprotein and an endogenous inhibitor of PP2A (Figure 9A).(44,45) The immunosuppressive property of FTY720 is induced by a phosphorylated form that activates sphingosine 1-phosphate receptors.(188) Subsequently, AAL(S) (21, Figure 4), an analog of FTY720, is identified with no immunosuppressive properties through structural optimization.(189) AAL(S) shows antitumor activity in acute myeloid leukemia cells and PP2A activation activity, which further supports the former PP2A activation antitumor mechanism of FTY720.(41,42) After PP2A is activated, the downstream signal factors of PP2A (pAkt, p70S6k/p85S6k, pRb) are significantly decreased, which induces G0/G1 cell cycle arrest in the cell cycle and finally results in apoptosis (Figure 9B).(124)

    3.2.2. Ro 90-7051

    In 2017, Hong et al. discovered Ro 90-7051 as a PP5 inhibitor with a unique TPR-dependent inhibitory mechanism.(122) As shown in Figure 10, they performed high-throughput screening of the Library of Pharmacologically Active Compounds (LOPAC1280) through the p-nitrophenyl phosphate assay. Then, they designed different PP5 deletion constructs to explore the potential functional mechanism of Ro 90-7051. The results showed that Ro 90-7051 strongly inhibits PP5 when the TPR domain is intact and seemingly acts as a “molecular glue” to bind the TPR domain, thus maintaining the autoinhibitory conformation of PP5.(122) Due to the similar features among the catalytic sites of PPPases, targeting the TPR domain may be a prerequisite property for the development of PP5-specific phosphatase inhibitors. Ro 90-7051 is a promising lead compound for cancer therapy that acts in a TPR-dependent inhibition manner on PP5.(122)

    3.2.3. P5SA-2

    In 2015, Haslbeck et al. identified P5SA-2 (22, Figure 4 and Table 1) as an allosteric PP5 activator by high-throughput screening.(121) As shown in Figure 11, they screened a compound library with 10000 compounds using a chromogenic phosphatase assay.(121) By the characterization of enzyme kinetic parameters and NMR analysis, P5SA-2 was identified as an allosteric activator of PP5. At a concentration of 100 μM, P5SA-2 increased the activity of PP5 over 4-fold higher than the basal activity. In contrast to other reported activators, such as arachidonic acid(54) and chaulmoogric acid(190) (respectively, 23 and 24, Figure 4), P5SA-2 activates PP5 in a TPR-independent manner. Although P5SA-2 is failed to modeled with PP5, the X-ray structure and mutation studies imply the binding sites for P5SA-2.(121) A 10° tilt of the TPR domain and a rearrangement of the αJ helix are observed when P5SA-2 binds to PP5 (Figure 11). The complete loss of activation effect of P5SA-2 is observed with amino acids mutation, including M455A, N457A, E428A, V429A, and K430A, implying the potential binding sites of the activator. Although the comprehensive activation mechanism of P5SA-2 is still unclear, it provides a new mechanism for the development of small molecules by allosterically targeting PPPases and might open a door to treat diseases triggered by hyperphosphorylation.(191)
    In brief, these noncatalytic functional domains, regulatory subunits, or other regulatory proteins together determine the diverse structures and specific biological functions of PPPases, and targeting noncatalytic subunits/domains is another potential strategy for cancer therapy. The discovery of FTY720, Ro 90-7051, and P5SA-2 has indicated the feasibility of this strategy. There are still some difficulties in this strategy, including a lack of adequate knowledge of PPPases structures and biological functions. For example, PP5 adopts an autoinhibitory mechanism through the TPR domain and αJ helix to regulate its activity, but the conformational changes and the specific amino residues involved in the activity transition are still unclear, which hinders the development of selective small molecules targeting the unique domain of PP5. Thus, more in-depth studies on the regulation of PPPase activity are needed.

    3.3. Small Molecules Targeting Holoenzymes

    3.3.1. Perphenazine and Its Analogs

    Perphenazine (PPZ, 25, Figure 4 and Table 1) is a phenothiazine antipsychotic drug that targets dopamine and related receptors in the cerebral cortex and was approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in 1956. Furthermore, it is a well-known multitarget compound and requires more comprehensive study.(192)
    In 2014, Gutierrez et al. identified PP2A as a potential target for PPZ. PPZ activates PP2A to promote the dephosphorylation of downstream substrates (p-Akt, p-p70S6K, p-BAD) and induces the apoptosis of T cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) cells.(131) Unfortunately, the inevitable extrapyramidal and anticholinergic effects involved in antipsychotic mechanisms preclude its further clinical research as an antitumor drug. In 2020, their group reported a small molecule, iHAP1 (a PPZ analog), that specifically activates PP2A and shows no inhibition on dopamine receptor.(15) To achieve this goal, 91 compounds containing PPZ, PPZ analogs (5 FDA approved compounds and 81 commercially available compounds), and 4 dopamine receptor D2 (DRD2) inhibitors (not related to the PPZ structure) were screened by KOPT-K1 cell antiproliferation, PP2A activation, and DRD2 inhibition assays. Compared with PPZ, the analog iHAP1 exhibits stronger PP2A activation activity (over 10-fold), undetectable DRD2 inhibitory activity, and improved antiproliferation effects. iHAP1 specifically activates the PP2A holoenzyme, which contains B56ε regulatory subunit (PP2A-B56ε), to promote dephosphorylation of MYBL2 (v-myb avian myeloblastosis viral oncogene homologue-like 2) at Ser241, finally causing cancer cells apoptosis by arresting the cell cycle in prometaphase. Thus, iHAP1 shows marked antiproliferative activities in leukemia cells and neuroblastoma cells (Figure 12A). Unfortunately, the binding mode of iHAP1 remains unclear.
    In 2015, Kastrinsky et al. adapted another method to avoid the dopamine receptor-mediated antipsychotic activity of PPZ. They probed the anticancer pharmacophores of PPZ by deleting and replacing central nervous systems (CNS) pharmacophores.(193) They evaluated those compounds by MTT cell viability assay and obtained a series of potent compounds that were later named SMAPs (small-molecule activators of PP2A).(194) They also uncovered that PPZ directly binds to the scaffold Aα subunit of PP2A and revealed a novel antitumor mechanism by which PPZ activates PP2A to inhibit the PI3K-AKT and RAS-ERK signaling pathways. In 2017, their group utilized KRAS mutant lung cancer mouse xenografts and transgenic models to demonstrate that SMAP (also named DT-061) inhibits the growth of these types cancer cells.(194) A mutation study also demonstrated that DT-061 activates PP2A by binding to the scaffold Aα subunit and inducing a conformational change in PP2A. Due to its unique regulatory mechanism, DT-061 selectively stabilizes PP2A-B56α trimers, thus dephosphorylating specific substrates.(14) In contrast to iHAP1, which activates the B56ε-containing PP2A and dephosphorylates MYBL2, SMAPs activate the B56α-containing PP2A, induce the dephosphorylation of c-MYC and ERK, and arrest the cell cycle in G0/G1 phase (Figure 12A). Thus, SMAPs show antitumor activities against MYC-driven cancers (T-ALL, Burkitt lymphoma, KRAS-driven nonsmall-cell lung cancer, and triple-negative breast cancer) and EGFR-driven cancer (lung adenocarcinoma).(14,193,195) Importantly, a cocrystal structure (PDB code: 6NTS)(14) of the PP2A-DT-061 complex was solved at 3.6 Å in 2020 by single-particle cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM). As shown in Figure 12B, DT-061 works as a “molecular glue” that is located in a pocket formed by the intersection interface of three PP2A subunits (including the scaffold Aα subunit (A subunit), catalytic Cα subunit (C subunit), and B56α regulatory subunit (B subunit)) and forms multiple types of interactions with all three subunits to stabilize the PP2A heterotrimers. The trifluoromethoxy part inserts into a pocket and forms electrostatic interactions with both the A subunit through Glu100 and Glu101 and the B subunit through Lys316. The benzene ring is buried in a hydrophobic region composed of Ile237, Tyr238, and Phe317 of the B subunit and Phe308 of the C subunit. The sulfonyl group interacts with Lys283 of the B subunit through electrostatic interactions. The phenoxazine moiety is exposed to the solvent region and forms hydrophobic interactions with Thr102 and Val103 of the A subunit and electrostatic interactions with Pro305 and Tyr307 of the B subunit. The C-tail of the A subunit is swinging freely before DT-061 attachment, and it is fixed in the crack between A subunit and B subunit after the interaction formed between the phenoxazine moiety of DT-061 and AB subunits.

    3.3.2. Macrolide Inhibitors

    Cyclosporine A (CsA) is a cyclic peptide (Figure 13A) extracted from the fungus Tolypocladium inflatum, which is initially named “ovalicin” and manufactured by Novartis (previously known as Sandoz).(197,198) Tacrolimus (also known as FK-506 or fujimycin) is isolated from Streptomyces tsukubaensis and originally developed by Astellas Pharma. Both of them are initially developed as immunosuppressants to reduce the risk of organ rejection after organ transplantation. CsA and FK-506 have similar biological properties and mechanisms.(199,200) CsA and FK-506 were approved by the FDA in 1983 and 1994, respectively. In the process of exploring their mechanisms, PP3 is identified as a target.(133,134) Before combining with PP3, CsA and FK-506 first form a binary complex with immunophilins, their specific carrier protein. Immunophilins are highly conserved and ubiquitously expressed with peptidylprolyl isomerase activity, and they are mainly divided into two types: cyclophilins (Cyp, for CsA binding) and FK-506 binding proteins (FKBPs).(201−204) Recently, they were found to exhibit antitumor effects in cancers, including colorectal cancer,(46) breast cancer,(47) bladder cancer,(48) lung cancer,(205,206) oral squamous cell carcinoma,(207) and other cancers.(47,205−208)
    CsA and FK-506 selectively inhibit PP3 with comparable inhibitory activities (the IC50 value were 7 nM and 0.4 nM, respectively) and show no effects on other PPPases.(134) Masuo et al. investigated the role of PP3 in the development of cancers and found that PP3 promotes cancer cells proliferation through the NFAT pathway.(46) In colorectal cancer, PP3 promotes cancer cell proliferation probably by regulating the levels of c-Myc, the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA), and p21 (WAF1/CIP1).(46) As shown in Figure 13B, the proliferation of colon cancer cells is blocked after CsA treatment, and the expression of c-Myc and PCNA is decreased, while that of p21 (WAF1/CIP1) is increased. In bladder cancer and prostate cancer, CsA and FK-506 attenuate NFAT transcriptional activity and decrease the expression of NFATc1 and the downstream proteins cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) and c-Myc. In addition, several tumor suppressor genes, such as p53, p21, and p27, are upregulated, and some oncogenic genes are downregulated, including cyclin D1, cyclin D3, and cyclin E.(48,209) CsA and FK-506 retard tumor growth by inhibiting proliferation, migration, and invasion and promoting apoptosis. In addition to evidence from the Masuo group, other evidence also revealed the antitumor activities of CsA and FK-506 on other cancers.(47,205−208) In a breast cancer model, pyruvate kinase M2 (PKM2) is overexpressed which is closely related to the usage of glycolytic intermediates for macromolecular biosynthesis and tumor growth. Treatment with CsA can significantly downregulate the expression of PKM2 and reduce ATP synthesis, which induces cancer cell necrosis.(47) Other cancers, including lung cancer and oral squamous cell carcinoma, are also response to CsA.(205−208)
    The cocrystal structures of both CsA-immunophilin complex and FK-506-immunophilin complex revealed similar binding sites on PP3.(196,210) Here, we just take CsA as an example to introduce its potential regulation mechanism and binding mode (PDB code:1MF8).(196) As shown in Figure 13B, the binding sites are far away from the catalytic sites of CnA (catalytic subunit of PP3). The CsA-Cyp complex interacts with both CnA and CnB (Calcineurin B) mainly through hydrophobic interactions and hydrogen bonds.(196) There are two hydrophobic surfaces in PP3: hydrophobic surface A (HSA) is composed of CnALeu343, CnAPro344, CnATrp352, CnASer353, CnAPhe356, CnBMet118, CnBVal119, CnBAsn122, and CnBLeu123; and hydrophobic surface B (HSB) is composed of CnALeu312 and CnAVal314. HSA forms primary hydrophobic interactions with Sar3, MeLeu4, Val5, MeLeu6, and Ala7 of CsA. HSB interacts with Ala8 and MeLeu9 of CsA. Among them, the side chain of CsAMeLeu4 inserts into a hydrophobic pocket composed of CnATrp352, CnASer353, CnAPhe356, CnBMet118, and CnBVal119. There are two hydrogen bonds formed by the carbonyl of CsAVal5 and indole NH of CnATrp352 and the amine NH of CsAVal7 and phenolic hydroxyl of CnATyr341. In short, the CsA-Cyp complex interacts with both the catalytic subunit and regulatory subunits of PP3 and covers the active sites of PP3 catalytic subunit to block access to the substrate protein.
    As shown above, small molecules targeting holoenzymes are another promising strategy to selectively modulate different PPPases or even different holoenzymes of one PPPase subfamily. iHAP1 and DT-061 interact with different B56-containing PP2A holoenzymes and specifically dephosphorylate different substrates of PP2A, thus inducing cancer cell apoptosis through different mechanisms. CsA and FK-506 selectively inhibit PP3 by binding to the heterodimer and retard proliferation of diverse cancer cells. As mentioned in Section 3.2, the challenge in developing small molecules targeting holoenzymes also is the lack of the knowledge of the conformational changes in the activity transition of PPPases.
    With so many reported compounds targeting PPPases, PPPases have broken the prejudice of undruggability and have gradually attracted the attention of medicinal chemists.(211) Based on the current research results, small molecules targeting catalytic subunits, targeting noncatalytic subunits/domains, or targeting holoenzymes are all feasible ways to develop antitumor drugs by modulating PPPases. Compared with strategies targeting noncatalytic subunits/domains and holoenzymes, targeting catalytic subunits is easier with many reported ligand-PPPase cocrystal structures, which provides many essential clues to design small molecules. None of the existing small molecules targeting catalytic subunits are selective, which is the main difficulty in optimizing current small molecules or developing new small molecules with new scaffolds. It is easier to achieve selectivity by targeting noncatalytic subunits/domains or holoenzymes, but the lack of knowledge of the conformational changes in the activity transitions of PPPases is an obstacle hindering the development of these two strategies. Fortunately, many small molecules have been reported, which could provide guidance and references for the development of new candidates for cancer therapy.

    4. Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    It is exciting to witness those possible ways of the development of the small molecules targeting PPPases in recent years. In this review, we summarize not only the structural features of different PPPases but also the related small molecules with disparate regulation mechanisms. With the accumulated evidence, it could be speculated that PPPases are highly involved in cancers. Thus, the rational design of small molecules targeting PPPases with high potency and specificity has become an urgent mission. Among all the potential strategies, directly targeting the catalytic subunits of PPPases remains an effective approach, although challenges still exist for the negatively charged binding domain and the lack of subtype specificity. Interestingly, targeting specific conserved cysteine residues on the surface of PPPases catalytic subunits makes covalent binding available and increases the selectivity of small molecules, which might provide another feasible way for developing PPPase modulators with improved binding potency and specificity. Targeting noncatalytic subunits/domains or holoenzymes is another promising way to design small molecules with better druggability and selectivity. Although the full scope of PPPases activity regulation has not been revealed, the success of the above-mentioned small molecules could provide guidance and references for the development of subsequent small molecules for cancer therapy. Notably, many small molecules originate from the new repurposing of old drugs, such as PPZ, FK-506, CsA, and FTY720, which may become a source of PPPase modulators screening. Taken together, these findings indicate that developing PPPase modulators is a promising strategy for cancer therapy, and it is foreseeable that PPPase modulators will occupy an important position in the development of antitumor drugs.

    adenosine triphosphate

    BAD

    Bcl-2-associated death promoter

    CaM

    Ca2+-calmodulin

    AI

    autoinhibitory domain

    Cn

    calcineurin

    Cdc25c

    cell division cycle 25c

    CsA

    cyclosporine A

    CNS

    central nervous systems

    Cyp

    cyclophilins

    CnA

    subunit A of calcineurin, CnB, subunit B of calcineurin

    CIP1

    CDK (cyclin-dependent kinase)-interacting protein 1

    COX-2

    cyclooxygenase-2

    DDR

    DNA damage repair

    DRD2

    dopamine receptor D2

    ERK

    extracellular-signal regulated kinase

    FDA

    the Food and Drug Administration

    γH2AX

    phosphorylated H2A histone family member X

    HRR

    homologous recombination repair

    HIF-1α

    hypoxia-inducible factor-1α

    HSA

    hydrophobic surface A

    HSB

    hydrophobic surface B

    c-Jun N-terminal kinase

    murine double minute 2

    v-myb avian myeloblastosis viral oncogene homologue-like 2

    maximum-tolerated dose

    ND

    not determined

    N-CoR

    nuclear receptor corepressor

    polo-like kinase 1

    phosphoprotein phosphatases

    protein phosphatase 1

    PP2A

    protein phosphatase 2A

    PP2B

    protein phosphatase 2B

    PP3

    protein phosphatase 3

    PP4

    protein phosphatase 4

    PP5

    protein phosphatase 5

    PP6

    protein phosphatase 6

    PP7

    protein phosphatase 7

    protein phosphatases with EF-hand domains

    PIPs

    PP1-interacting proteins

    pRb

    phosphorylated retinoblastoma

    PK

    pharmacokinetics

    PPZ

    phenothiazine

    PCNA

    the proliferating cell nuclear antigen

    pyruvate kinase M2

    phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase

    Rb

    retinoblastoma

    RAS

    reticular activating system

    SMAPs

    small-molecule activators of PP2A

    SET

    SET domain containing protein (domain containing is a 130–140 amino acid, evolutionary well conserved sequence motif that was initially characterized in the Drosophila proteins Su (var.)3-9, Enhancer-of-zeste and Trithorax)

    STAT1

    signal transducer and activator of transcription 1

    TPR

    tetratricopeptide repeat

    T-ALL

    lymphoblastic leukemia

    VEGF

    vascular endothelial growth factor

      Global, in vivo, and site-specific phosphorylation dynamics in signaling networks
      Olsen, Jesper V.; Blagoev, Blagoy; Gnad, Florian; Macek, Boris; Kumar, Chanchai; Mortensen, Peter; Mann, Matthias
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2006), 127 (3), 635-648CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      Cell signaling mechanisms often transmit information via posttranslational protein modifications, most importantly reversible protein phosphorylation. Here we develop and apply a general mass spectrometric technol. for identification and quantitation of phosphorylation sites as a function of stimulus, time, and subcellular location. We have detected 6600 phosphorylation sites on 2244 proteins and have detd. their temporal dynamics after stimulating HeLa cells with epidermal growth factor (EGF) and recorded them in the Phosida database. Fourteen percent of phosphorylation sites are modulated at least 2-fold by EG, and these were classified by their temporal profiles. Surprisingly, a majority of proteins contain multiple phosphorylation sites showing different kinetics, suggesting that they serve as platforms for integrating signals. In addn. to protein kinase cascades, the targets of reversible phosphorylation include ubiquitin ligases, guanine nucleotide exchange factors, and at least 46 different transcriptional regulators. The dynamic phosphoproteome provides a missing link in a global, integrative view of cellular regulation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xht1WgtbzO&md5=c8f9ef184663cabfda0db5958549166c
    2. 2
      Holt, L. J.; Tuch, B. B.; Villen, J.; Johnson, A. D.; Gygi, S. P.; Morgan, D. O. Global Analysis of Cdk1 Substrate Phosphorylation Sites Provides Insights into Evolution. Science 2009, 325, 1682– 1686,  DOI: 10.1126/science.1172867
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Global Analysis of Cdk1 Substrate Phosphorylation Sites Provides Insights into Evolution
      Holt, Liam J.; Tuch, Brian B.; Villen, Judit; Johnson, Alexander D.; Gygi, Steven P.; Morgan, David O.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2009), 325 (5948), 1682-1686CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      To explore the mechanisms and evolution of cell-cycle control, we analyzed the position and conservation of large nos. of phosphorylation sites for the cyclin-dependent kinase Cdk1 in the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We combined specific chem. inhibition of Cdk1 with quant. mass spectrometry to identify the positions of 547 phosphorylation sites on 308 Cdk1 substrates in vivo. Comparisons of these substrates with orthologs throughout the ascomycete lineage revealed that the position of most phosphorylation sites is not conserved in evolution; instead, clusters of sites shift position in rapidly evolving disordered regions. We propose that the regulation of protein function by phosphorylation often depends on simple nonspecific mechanisms that disrupt or enhance protein-protein interactions. The gain or loss of phosphorylation sites in rapidly evolving regions could facilitate the evolution of kinase signaling circuits.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtFGqt7%252FP&md5=27178a3c1791d046fa801e47cac844be
    3. 3
      Serber, Z.; Ferrell, J. E. Tuning Bulk Electrostatics to Regulate Protein Function. Cell 2007, 128, 441– 444,  DOI: 10.1016/j.cell.2007.01.018
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Tuning bulk electrostatics to regulate protein function
      Serber, Zach; Ferrell, James E., Jr.
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2007), 128 (3), 441-444CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      A review. Cyclin-dependent kinase activation can prevent yeast cells from responding to mating pheromone. Strickfaden et al. (2007) now show that this block arises from the multisite phosphorylation of Ste5. This provides a beautiful example of how phosphorylation can produce decisive changes in protein function through bulk electrostatics, without the necessity of intricate conformational changes.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXit1Wlt7s%253D&md5=7c5c434214d2b0722fbc656592b8dee2
    4. 4
      Ruvolo, P. P. Role of Protein Phosphatases in the Cancer Microenvironment. Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Mol. Cell Res. 2019, 1866, 144– 152,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bbamcr.2018.07.006
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Role of protein phosphatases in the cancer microenvironment
      Ruvolo, Peter P.
      Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Molecular Cell Research (2019), 1866 (1), 144-152CODEN: BBAMCO; ISSN:0167-4889. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Cancer cells depend on a supportive niche (the tumor microenvironment) that promotes tumor cell survival while protecting the malignant cells from therapeutic challenges and the host's defense systems. Cancer cells and the support cells in the tumor microenvironment communicate via cytokines/chemokines, cell:cell contact, or alterations in the metabolic state of the niche (e.g. hypoxia) that promote growth and survival of the tumor cell, influence metastasis, and defeat immune surveillance. These signaling pathways involve dysregulation of not only protein kinases but also protein phosphatases as normal signal transduction processes require both activation and deactivation. For instance, aberrant receptor signaling can result from constitutive activation of a tyrosine kinase such as FLT3 or inactivation of a tyrosine protein phosphatase such as SHP-2 (PTPN11). Activation of serine/threonine kinases such as AKT and ERK are often obsd. during the development of drug resistance while genomic and non-genomic suppression of serine/threonine protein phosphatases such as PP2A achieve similar results. It is fairly clear that the various protein phosphatases will impact processes that support drug resistance. Of growing interest is the emerging model whereby the support cells in the tumor microenvironment actually serve as drivers of tumorigenesis. This phenomenon has been most prominently obsd. in osteoblast cells in leukemic niches. At least one protein phosphatase, PTPN11, has emerged as a crit. driver of this process in juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia. This review will cover the role of various serine/threonine and tyrosine protein phosphatases in processes that are central to tumor microenvironment function.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtlCltLjI&md5=fed1fbf4b19c201807dd3193fe835df9
    5. 5
      Moura, M.; Conde, C. Phosphatases in Mitosis: Roles and Regulation. Biomolecules 2019, 9, 55,  DOI: 10.3390/biom9020055
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Phosphatases in mitosis: roles and regulation
      Moura, Margarida; Conde, Carlos
      Biomolecules (2019), 9 (2), 55/1-55/51CODEN: BIOMHC; ISSN:2218-273X. (MDPI AG)
      A review. Mitosis requires extensive rearrangement of cellular architecture and of subcellular structures so that replicated chromosomes can bind correctly to spindle microtubules and segregate towards opposite poles. This process originates two new daughter nuclei with equal genetic content and relies on highly-dynamic and tightly regulated phosphorylation of numerous cell cycle proteins. A burst in protein phosphorylation orchestrated by several conserved kinases occurs as cells go into and progress through mitosis. The opposing dephosphorylation events are catalyzed by a small set of protein phosphatases, whose importance for the accuracy of mitosis is becoming increasingly appreciated. This review will focus on the established and emerging roles of mitotic phosphatases, describe their structural and biochem. properties, and discuss recent advances in understanding the regulation of phosphatase activity and function.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXnvVehsL8%253D&md5=d42a0ee9edc8b35dd656b20b33a9a742
    6. 6
      Brautigan, D. L.; Shenolikar, S. Protein Serine/Threonine Phosphatases: Keys to Unlocking Regulators and Substrates. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 2018, 87, 921– 964,  DOI: 10.1146/annurev-biochem-062917-012332
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Protein Serine/Threonine Phosphatases: Keys to Unlocking Regulators and Substrates
      Brautigan, David L.; Shenolikar, Shirish
      Annual Review of Biochemistry (2018), 87 (), 921-964CODEN: ARBOAW; ISSN:0066-4154. (Annual Reviews)
      A review. Protein serine/threonine phosphatases (PPPs) are ancient enzymes, with distinct types conserved across eukaryotic evolution. PPPs are segregated into types primarily on the basis of the unique interactions of PPP catalytic subunits with regulatory proteins. The resulting holoenzymes dock substrates distal to the active site to enhance specificity. This review focuses on the subunit and substrate interactions for PPP that depend on short linear motifs. Insights about these motifs from structures of holoenzymes open new opportunities for computational biol. approaches to elucidate PPP networks. There is an expanding knowledge base of posttranslational modifications of PPP catalytic and regulatory subunits, as well as of their substrates, including phosphorylation, acetylation, and ubiquitination. Cross talk between these posttranslational modifications creates PPP-based signaling. Knowledge of PPP complexes, signaling clusters, as well as how PPPs communicate with each other in response to cellular signals should unlock the doors to PPP networks and signaling "clouds" that orchestrate and coordinate different aspects of cell physiol.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtFOrsrrL&md5=dc58f68ce05dd5535e8ce0c7e1d5036d
    7. 7
      De Munter, S.; Köhn, M.; Bollen, M. Challenges and Opportunities in the Development of Protein Phosphatase-Directed Therapeutics. ACS Chem. Biol. 2013, 8, 36– 45,  DOI: 10.1021/cb300597g
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Challenges and Opportunities in the Development of Protein Phosphatase-Directed Therapeutics
      De Munter, Sofie; Kohn, Maja; Bollen, Mathieu
      ACS Chemical Biology (2013), 8 (1), 36-45CODEN: ACBCCT; ISSN:1554-8929. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Protein phosphatases have both protective and promoting roles in the etiol. of diseases. A prominent example is the existence of oncogenic as well as tumor-suppressing protein phosphatases. A few protein phosphatase activity modulators are already applied in therapies. These were however not developed in target-directed approaches, and the recent discovery of phosphatase involvement followed their application in therapy. Nevertheless, these examples demonstrate that small mols. can be generated that modulate the activity of protein phosphatases and are beneficial for the treatment of protein phosphorylation diseases. We describe here strategies for the development of activators and inhibitors of protein phosphatases and clarify some long-standing misconceptions concerning the drug ability of these enzymes. Recent developments suggest that it is feasible to design potent and selective protein phosphatase modulators with a therapeutic potential.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhvVSjurrF&md5=a6bccc84309271ecdec328d6b1b84294
    8. 8
      Roskoski, R. Properties of Fda-Approved Small Molecule Protein Kinase Inhibitors. Pharmacol. Res. 2019, 144, 19– 50,  DOI: 10.1016/j.phrs.2019.03.006
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Properties of FDA-approved small molecule protein kinase inhibitors
      Roskoski, Robert Jr.
      Pharmacological Research (2019), 144 (), 19-50CODEN: PHMREP; ISSN:1043-6618. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. Because mutations, overexpression, and dysregulation of protein kinases play essential roles in the pathogenesis of many illnesses, this enzyme family has become one of the most important drug targets in the past 20 years. The US FDA has approved 48 small mol. protein kinase inhibitors, nearly all of which are orally effective with the exceptions of netarsudil (which is given as an eye drop) and temsirolimus (which is given i.v.). Of the 48 approved drugs, the majority (25) target receptor protein-tyrosine kinases, ten target non-receptor protein-tyrosine kinases, and 13 target protein-serine/threonine protein kinases. The data indicate that 43 of these drugs are used in the treatment of malignancies (36 against solid tumors including lymphomas and seven against non-solid tumors, e.g., leukemias). Seven drugs are used in the treatment of non-malignancies: baricitinib, rheumatoid arthritis; fostamatinib, chronic immune thrombocytopenia; ruxolitinib, myelofibrosis and polycythemia vera; nintedanib, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis; sirolimus, renal graft vs. host disease; netarsudil, glaucoma; tofacitinib, rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn disease, and ulcerative colitis. Moreover, ibrutinib and sirolimus are used for the treatment of both malignant and non-malignant diseases. The most common drug targets include ALK, B-Raf, BCR-Abl, epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), and vascular endothelial growth factor receptor (VEGFR). Most of the small mol. inhibitors (45) interact directly with the protein kinase domain. In contrast, sirolimus, temsirolimus, and everolimus are larger mols. (MW ≈ 1000) that bind to FKBP-12 to generate a complex that inhibits mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin). This review presents the available drug-enzyme X-ray crystal structures for 27 of the approved drugs as well as the chem. structures and physicochem. properties of all of the FDA-approved small mol. protein kinase antagonists. Six of the drugs bind covalently and irreversibly to their target. Twenty of the 48 drugs have mol. wts. greater than 500, exceeding a Lipinski rule of five criterion. Excluding the macrolides (everolimus, sirolimus, temsirolimus), the av. mol. wt. of drugs is 480 with a range of 306 (ruxolitinib) to 615 (trametinib). Nearly half of the antagonists (23) have a lipophilic efficiency with values of less than five while the recommended optima range from 5-10. One of the vexing problems is the near universal development of resistance that is assocd. with the use of small mol. protein kinase inhibitors for the treatment of cancer.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXntVGnurg%253D&md5=a24dee87603bc4ea12bd34616e46f53d

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      A review. Topics discussed include classification of protein phosphatases, natural phosphatase inhibitors, structural features of protein phosphatase inhibition and therapeutic use of protein phosphatase inhibitors.

    10. 10
      Bhullar, K. S.; Lagaron, N. O.; McGowan, E. M.; Parmar, I.; Jha, A.; Hubbard, B. P.; Rupasinghe, H. P. V. Kinase-Targeted Cancer Therapies: Progress, Challenges and Future Directions. Mol. Cancer 2018, 17, 48,  DOI: 10.1186/s12943-018-0804-2
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Kinase-targeted cancer therapies: progress, challenges and future directions
      Bhullar, Khushwant S.; Lagaron, Naiara Orrego; McGowan, Eileen M.; Parmar, Indu; Jha, Amitabh; Hubbard, Basil P.; Rupasinghe, H. P. Vasantha
      Molecular Cancer (2018), 17 (), 48/1-48/20CODEN: MCOACG; ISSN:1476-4598. (BioMed Central Ltd.)
      The human genome encodes 538 protein kinases that transfer a γ-phosphate group from ATP to serine, threonine, or tyrosine residues. Many of these kinases are assocd. with human cancer initiation and progression. The recent development of small-mol. kinase inhibitors for the treatment of diverse types of cancer has proven successful in clin. therapy. Significantly, protein kinases are the second most targeted group of drug targets, after the G-proteincoupled receptors. Since the development of the first protein kinase inhibitor, in the early 1980s, 37 kinase inhibitors have received FDA approval for treatment of malignancies such as breast and lung cancer. Furthermore, about 150 kinase-targeted drugs are in clin. phase trials, and many kinase-specific inhibitors are in the preclin. stage of drug development. Nevertheless, many factors confound the clin. efficacy of these mols. Specific tumor genetics, tumor microenvironment, drug resistance, and pharmacogenomics det. how useful a compd. will be in the treatment of a given cancer. This review provides an overview of kinase-targeted drug discovery and development in relation to oncol. and highlights the challenges and future potential for kinase-targeted cancer therapies.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXitF2nt7fP&md5=30811747f13749327d998c5dadd2161d
    11. 11
      Fahs, S.; Lujan, P.; Köhn, M. Approaches to Study Phosphatases. ACS Chem. Biol. 2016, 11, 2944– 2961,  DOI: 10.1021/acschembio.6b00570
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Approaches to Study Phosphatases
      Fahs, Sara; Lujan, Pablo; Koehn, Maja
      ACS Chemical Biology (2016), 11 (11), 2944-2961CODEN: ACBCCT; ISSN:1554-8929. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Phosphatases play key roles in normal physiol. and diseases. Studying phosphatases has been both essential and challenging, and the application of conventional genetic and biochem. methods has led to crucial but still limited understanding of their mechanisms, substrates, and exclusive functions within highly intricate networks. With the advances in technologies such as cellular imaging and mol. and chem. biol. in terms of sensitive tools and methods, the phosphatase field has thrived in the past years and has set new insights for cell signaling studies and for therapeutic development. In this review, we give an overview of the existing interdisciplinary tools for phosphatases, give examples on how they have been applied to increase our understanding of these enzymes, and suggest how they - and other tools yet barely used in the phosphatase field - might be adapted to address future questions and challenges.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      12
      Protein tyrosine phosphatases - from housekeeping enzymes to master regulators of signal transduction
      Tonks, Nicholas K.
      FEBS Journal (2013), 280 (2), 346-378CODEN: FJEOAC; ISSN:1742-464X. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      A review. There are many misconceptions surrounding the roles of protein phosphatases in the regulation of signal transduction, perhaps the most damaging of which is the erroneous view that these enzymes exert their effects merely as constitutively active housekeeping enzymes. On the contrary, the phosphatases are crit., specific regulators of signalling in their own right and serve an essential function, in a coordinated manner with the kinases, to det. the response to a physiol. stimulus. This review is a personal perspective on the development of our understanding of the protein tyrosine phosphatase family of enzymes. I have discussed various aspects of the structure, regulation and function of the protein tyrosine phosphatase family, which I hope will illustrate the fundamental importance of these enzymes in the control of signal transduction.

      14
      Selective PP2A enhancement through biased heterotrimer stabilization
      Leonard, Daniel; Huang, Wei; Izadmehr, Sudeh; O'Connor, Caitlin M.; Wiredja, Danica D.; Wang, Zhizhi; Zaware, Nilesh; Chen, Yinghua; Schlatzer, Daniela M.; Kiselar, Janna; Vasireddi, Nikhil; Schuchner, Stefan; Perl, Abbey L.; Galsky, Matthew D.; Xu, Wenqing; Brautigan, David L.; Ogris, Egon; Taylor, Derek J.; Narla, Goutham
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2020), 181 (3), 688-701.e16CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      Impairment of protein phosphatases, including the family of serine/threonine phosphatases designated PP2A, is essential for the pathogenesis of many diseases, including cancer. The ability of PP2A to dephosphorylate hundreds of proteins is regulated by over 40 specificity-detg. regulatory "B" subunits that compete for assembly and activation of heterogeneous PP2A heterotrimers. Here, we reveal how a small mol., DT-061, specifically stabilizes the B56α-PP2A holoenzyme in a fully assembled, active state to dephosphorylate selective substrates, such as its well-known oncogenic target, c-Myc. Our 3.6 Å structure identifies mol. interactions between DT-061 and all three PP2A subunits that prevent dissocn. of the active enzyme and highlight inherent mechanisms of PP2A complex assembly. Thus, our findings provide fundamental insights into PP2A complex assembly and regulation, identify a unique interfacial stabilizing mode of action for therapeutic targeting, and aid in the development of phosphatase-based therapeutics tailored against disease specific phospho-protein targets.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXnvFeitL4%253D&md5=baeee6ee120e38c807e69ad60845cf58
    15. 15
      Morita, K.; He, S.; Nowak, R. P.; Wang, J.; Zimmerman, M. W.; Fu, C.; Durbin, A. D.; Martel, M. W.; Prutsch, N.; Gray, N. S.; Fischer, E. S.; Look, A. T. Allosteric Activators of Protein Phosphatase 2a Display Broad Antitumor Activity Mediated by Dephosphorylation of Mybl2. Cell 2020, 181, 702– 715,  DOI: 10.1016/j.cell.2020.03.051
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      15
      Allosteric Activators of Protein Phosphatase 2A Display Broad Antitumor Activity Mediated by Dephosphorylation of MYBL2
      Morita, Ken; He, Shuning; Nowak, Radoslaw P.; Wang, Jinhua; Zimmerman, Mark W.; Fu, Cong; Durbin, Adam D.; Martel, Megan W.; Prutsch, Nicole; Gray, Nathanael S.; Fischer, Eric S.; Look, A. Thomas
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2020), 181 (3), 702-715.e20CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      Protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A) enzymes can suppress tumors, but they are often inactivated in human cancers overexpressing inhibitory proteins. Here, we identify a class of small-mol. iHAPs (improved heterocyclic activators of PP2A) that kill leukemia cells by allosterically assembling a specific heterotrimeric PP2A holoenzyme consisting of PPP2R1A (scaffold), PPP2R5E (B56ε, regulatory), and PPP2CA (catalytic) subunits. One compd., iHAP1, activates this complex but does not inhibit dopamine receptor D2, a mediator of neurol. toxicity induced by perphenazine and related neuroleptics. The PP2A complex activated by iHAP1 dephosphorylates the MYBL2 transcription factor on Ser241, causing irreversible arrest of leukemia and other cancer cells in prometaphase. In contrast, SMAPs, a sep. class of compds., activate PP2A holoenzymes contg. a different regulatory subunit, do not dephosphorylate MYBL2, and arrest tumor cells in G1 phase. Our findings demonstrate that small mols. can serve as allosteric switches to activate distinct PP2A complexes with unique substrates.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
